Award.AwardTitle: CPS: TTP Option: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Certifiable, Scalable, and Attack-resilient Submodular Control Framework for Smart Grid Stability

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Exploiting inherent physical structure of the CPS domains can lead to economically viable and efficient novel algorithms for providing performance, control, synchronization and an alternate approach to CPS security that does not rely solely on cryptography. In each of these systems, regardless of the current state of the network, in the presence of disturbances or adversarial inputs, there is a need to bring the system to desired state for performance and control of the network.

This project presents one such novel approach by observing that the CPS applications including smartgrid, coordinating robotics, formation flights in UAV, and synchronization of biological systems including brain networks all exhibit a special physical structure, namely submodularity, with respect to the set of control actions. Submodularity is a diminishing returns property that enables the development of efficient algorithms with provable optimality guarantees and in many cases distributed versions that are locally implementable, and hence scalable. While it has been widely used in the machine learning and discrete optimization communities, the use of submodularity in the context of CPS is a fertile research area. This project initially applies submodularity in the context of smart grid and show how it can lead to greater system stability and attack resilience. By defining suitable metrics that capture the submodular structures underlying the physical dynamics, the researchers develop algorithms that eliminate the time-consuming and computationally expensive verification of control actions through simulation. The fundamental properties of synchronization, convergence, robustness, and attack-resilience considered in this effort have crosscutting applications to multiple CPS domains, which will benefit from the submodular approach that we will research and develop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Overview:

The ?smart grid? is a large-scale, societal-level hybrid cyber-physical system (CPS) with tight coupling between cyber and physical components. Ensuring availability and reliability of electric power requires maintaining the stability of the power grid even as increasing electricity demand and uncertain renewable power sources, such as solar and wind,  push the power system close to its operation limit. In addition, the cyber-enabled smart grid has multiple entry points, leaving it highly susceptible to cyber attacks by malicious adversaries. Developing scalable, certifiable, and attack-resilient control methodologies for smart grid stability is an important and critical research area for our nation?s power infrastructure. In our three-year project, we developed  control methodologies that are scalable, certifiable, and attack-resilient for the following power system problems: (i) voltage stability, (ii) small-signal stability, and (iii) transient stability, where cascading failures can devastate a power grid. Our main insight in our research was that the smart grid stability problems have inherent physical structures that exhibit ?submodularity? in terms of control variables. Submodularity is a diminishing returns property in the area of discrete-time optimization that enables development of practical, efficient algorithms with provable optimality guarantees. We developed algorithms to select control actions, such as switching capacitor banks or islanding power plants, with certifiable stability guarantees, thus eliminating the computationally expensive current practice of computing control actions and verifying stability through simulation. We also discovered that the submodular structures in the smart grid remain intact under cyber attacks.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Our research effort contributed to the basic science of CPS security. The project developed a submodular controller framework that enabled real-time response to instabilities in the electric power grid. The main goal is to restore the power grid to a stable operating point in a short time. Exploiting the inherent submodular structure of the smart grid?s physical properties was the key insight that enabled our development of certifiable, practical, and scalable control algorithms. Since submodularity is a property of the physical invariants of the smart grid, which remain even if measurement data or information exchanges are corrupted, our controllers are also resistant to cyber attacks by malicious adversaries. Specifically, the developed framework can be used to determine voltage stability, small-signal stability, and transient stability, which are important power system stability problems. The project outcomes will enhance the resilience of the smart grid and support the goal to cope with increasing power demand from users and uncertainties from distributed, renewable energy sources.

 

Broader Impact:

The project has a direct impact on the power systems industry in finding more efficient ways to stabilize the power grid after voltage instabilities or cascading failures. The submodular optimization tools we developed are fundamental, and thus can be applied to many other networked CPS, such as transportation, robotics, autonomous vehicles, social networks, and biological systems. By improving the stability and reliability of the smart grid, facilitating integration of renewable energy sources, and meeting ever-increasing energy demand, our project advances research in the technology and science of CPS. Results of the project were disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and the CPS-VO. We also incorporated the project results into the summer University of Washington Math Academy Workshop for underrepresented minority high school students.
